communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: SoMa West Community Benefit District
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

The SoMa West CBD was established in 2019, as of 2020-21 had an annual assessment of $3,859,195.14, and runs a Safety Ambassador Security Task Force:
https://sfmayor.org/article/mayor-london-breed-signs-legislation-establishing-soma-west-community-benefit-district
https://somawestcbd.org/
https://www.sf.gov/file/2022-san-francisco-property-business-improvement-district-pbid-program-impact-analysis
https://somawestcbd.org/post/safety-ambassadors-meet-and-greet-at-decant-sf

I request the following records:

1) Budget and annual financial statements for FY2023, FY2024, FY2025 and FY2026. This includes any documents (including but not limited to PDF, word processing, excel, and slide documents) related to the association's budget and financial statements, including both unaudited and audited statements, accounts receivable, balance sheets, revenue & expense statements, cashflow statements, annual financial audits, and any other financial planning documents. This also includes any information about financial reserve planning.

2) Any documents (including but not limited to PDF, word processing, excel, and slide documents) including contracts, purchase orders, invoices, financial plans, and financial reports related to the operations of the Safety Ambassador Security Task Force, since January 1 2023. This includes any documents about the purchase and maintenance of vehicles and staffing costs.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Maya Kaczorowski

communications.subject: Re: California Public Records Act Request: SoMa West Community Benefit District
communications.communication:
Greetings,
This message is to confirm that we have received your Records Request dated February 5, 2025.
You have requested the following records:
1) Budget and annual financial statements for FY2023, FY2024, FY2025 and FY2026. This includes any documents (including but not limited to PDF, word processing, excel, and slide documents) related to the association's budget and financial statements, including both unaudited and audited statements, accounts receivable, balance sheets, revenue & expense statements, cashflow statements, annual financial audits, and any other financial planning documents. This also includes any information about financial reserve planning.
2) Any documents (including but not limited to PDF, word processing, excel, and slide documents) including contracts, purchase orders, invoices, financial plans, and financial reports related to the operations of the Safety Ambassador Security Task Force, since January 1 2023. This includes any documents about the purchase and maintenance of vehicles and staffing costs.
Our department will conduct a search, compile and release any responsive records identified related to the requested information. The Sunshine Ordinance requires departments to respond as soon as possible or within 10 calendar days from receipt of any records requests.
Therefore, we will contact you on or before February 17, 2025, as permitted by San Francisco Administrative Code § 67.21(b) and California Government Code § 7922.535.
Sincerely,
The Office of Economic and Workforce Development

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: 2024 BPD Budget
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

The budget and actual spending of the Boston Police Department between January 1, 2024 and December 31, 2024 which fall under the following titles : “special events”, “central booking”, ”central lockup”, “regional lockup”, or “central booking transfers” or any which fall under costs related to the MEMORANDUM OF AGREEMENT FOR DETENTION OF ARRESTEES AT THE SUFFOLK COUNTY JAIL signed by the Suffolk County Sheriff's Department and the Boston Police Department.  

I also request the budget and expenditure to staff central booking facilities, as well as any and all payments made to the Suffolk sheriff’s department between January 1, 2024 and December 31, 2024.  

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Michael Lozada

To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any and all communications concerning the Austin Public Library's Enhanced Library Card program between employees of the City of Austin and federal agencies, including but not limited to Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and Border Patrol. This request should not be understood to be seeking personally identifiable information of ID holders. The date range for this request is from Oct. 1, 2024, to the present.

Please include any relevant emails, memos, reports, or other forms of communication that pertain to this matter.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Cory Dawson

title: Financial Records, Grant Allocations, and Correspondence Related to Connecticut Coalition Against Domestic Violence (CCADV) and Connecticut Comptroller’s Office (Office of the State Comptroller) (Office of the State Comptroller)

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Connecticut Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Pursuant to 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E), I demand expedited processing based on:
✅ Urgency of public interest – The request involves government transparency, potential conflicts of interest, and the use of taxpayer funds.
✅ Risk of improper financial influence – Given Sean Scanlon’s position as Connecticut Comptroller and Meghan Scanlon’s leadership at Connecticut CCADV, there is a clear need for immediate disclosure.To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Connecticut Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

02/01/2025
Financial Records, Grant Allocations, and Correspondence Related to Connecticut Coalition Against Domestic Violence (CCADV) and Connecticut Comptroller’s Office
Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) Request – Legally Binding Public Records Demand

To:
Due to the complexity of government agencies, departments, sub-departments, and committees involved in this request, and in light of my disability, I formally request that all recipients of this FOIA request forward it to any and all relevant offices, divisions, personnel, or agencies that may hold responsive records.

This request is made in accordance with FOIA (5 U.S.C. § 552), the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) (42 U.S.C. § 12132), and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. § 794), ensuring my full and equal access to government records. I ask for reasonable assistance in processing this request, including identifying appropriate record holders and ensuring that all relevant entities conduct a thorough search including but not limited to the the following people and agencies listed below.

Federal Bureau of Investigation FBI
Connecticut Office of the Comptroller
Connecticut Department of Social Services (DSS)
Connecticut Office of Policy and Management (OPM)
Connecticut Governor’s Office
Connecticut Office of Victim Services (OVS)
U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) – Office of the Inspector General (OIG)
U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) – Office on Violence Against Women

Date: February 1, 2025

Subject: Immediate FOIA Request – Financial Records, Grant Allocations, and Correspondence Related to Connecticut Coalition Against Domestic Violence (CCADV) and Connecticut Comptroller’s Office
This request is submitted under my constitutional rights, whistleblower protections, and taxpayer interests pursuant to the following laws:

✅ Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) (5 U.S.C. § 552)
✅ Connecticut FOIA laws (Conn. Gen. Stat. §§ 1-200 et seq.)
✅ First and Fifth Amendments (Freedom of Information & Due Process Rights)
✅ Whistleblower Protection Act (5 U.S.C. § 2302)
✅ False Claims Act (31 U.S.C. §§ 3729–3733)
✅ Federal Funding Accountability and Transparency Act (31 U.S.C. § 6101)
✅ Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) (42 U.S.C. § 12101 et seq.)
✅ Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. § 794)

This FOIA request is made in the interest of government accountability, financial oversight, and transparency regarding Connecticut’s Medicaid ABI Waiver Program and potential conflicts of interest involving CCADV and the Connecticut Comptroller’s Office.

1. Connecticut State Budget Allocations to CCADV (2020–2025)
🔹 All state budget line items, funding allocations, and appropriations for domestic violence programs that provided funding to CCADV.
🔹 All discretionary grants, direct payments, or non-competitive funding allocations made to CCADV from Connecticut state agencies, including but not limited to DSS, OPM, and the Office of the Comptroller.
🔹 Records of budget changes, funding increases, or discretionary payments to CCADV since Meghan Scanlon became CEO.
🔹 Financial audits, budget justifications, and accountability reports related to CCADV funding.

2. Connecticut Comptroller’s Office – Transactions & Financial Oversight of CCADV
🔹 All financial disbursements from the Connecticut Comptroller’s Office to CCADV or any of its affiliated programs (2020-2025).
🔹 All contracts, agreements, invoices, or purchase orders involving the Connecticut Comptroller’s Office and CCADV.
🔹 All internal communications, memos, or correspondence related to CCADV funding, financial oversight, or policy decisions.

3. Connecticut Department of Social Services (DSS) – Grant Funding to CCADV
🔹 All contracts, agreements, and funding disbursement records between DSS and CCADV.
🔹 All emails, memos, or correspondence between DSS officials and CCADV leadership (including Meghan Scanlon) regarding funding, policies, or budget increases.
🔹 Records of grant application processes, funding approval criteria, and justification for any discretionary funding increases to CCADV.

4. Connecticut Office of Policy and Management (OPM) – Discretionary Funding Oversight
🔹 All financial records and internal communications regarding CCADV’s funding through discretionary grants or state allocations.
🔹 All documentation detailing OPM’s approval, oversight, and monitoring of funds allocated to CCADV.

5. Governor’s Office – Policy Influence & CCADV Funding
🔹 All communications (emails, memos, reports) between the Governor’s Office and CCADV leadership regarding funding, legislative priorities, or advocacy initiatives.
🔹 All meeting minutes, directives, or internal memos discussing the Governor’s role in funding CCADV or influencing domestic violence program funding.

6. Connecticut Office of Victim Services (OVS) – Judicial Branch Grant Funding to CCADV
🔹 All financial records, grant allocations, and award justifications given to CCADV through OVS.
🔹 All documentation related to federal VOCA (Victims of Crime Act) and VAWA (Violence Against Women Act) grants distributed to CCADV through state agencies.

7. Federal Oversight – U.S. DOJ & HHS Inspector General
🔹 All federal grant distributions (FVPSA, VAWA, VOCA) allocated to CCADV through Connecticut agencies.
🔹 All audits, compliance reviews, or fraud investigations into CCADV’s use of state or federal funding.
🔹 All records related to whistleblower complaints, fraud disclosures, or conflicts of interest concerning CCADV and state agencies.

8. Legal Mandates for Compliance
✅ National Archives & Records Administration v. Favish, 541 U.S. 157 (2004) – Government transparency is a constitutional right.
✅ Judicial Watch v. DHS, 857 F.3d 564 (D.C. Cir. 2017) – Agencies must provide evidence that no records exist.
✅ Burlington Northern & Santa Fe Railway Co. v. White, 548 U.S. 53 (2006) – Government retaliation includes obstructing access to information.

EXPEDITED PROCESSING REQUEST
Pursuant to 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E), I demand expedited processing based on:
✅ Urgency of public interest – The request involves government transparency, potential conflicts of interest, and the use of taxpayer funds.
✅ Risk of improper financial influence – Given Sean Scanlon’s position as Comptroller and Meghan Scanlon’s leadership at CCADV, there is a clear need for immediate disclosure.

ADA & Civil Rights Accommodations
Under Title II of the ADA (42 U.S.C. § 12132) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. § 794), I demand:
ADA Accommodations Request
This request includes explicit ADA accommodations to address cognitive processing challenges resulting from my traumatic brain injury (TBI). These accommodations are legally required under Title II of the ADA (42 U.S.C. § 12132)
and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. § 794).

Requested ADA Accommodations
To ensure accessibility and compliance with ADA standards (42 U.S.C. § 12101 et seq.), I request the following accommodations for all communications and records:
Screen-Reader Compatible Formats

All documents must be provided in properly labeled PDFs or plain-text files.
Ensure that the documents are screen-reader compatible and retain clear, accessible formatting.
Exclusive MuckRock Platform Communication
All communications must occur exclusively via the MuckRock platform.
Do not send external links, emails, portals, passwords, codes, or require phone calls for access.
Text Embedded in Email Bodies

Key information must be embedded directly in the email body to facilitate comprehension and accessibility.

Simplified Summaries
Provide plain-language summaries for complex or legal documents to ensure clarity and understanding.

Identification of Responsible Officers
Include the full name, title, and contact information of all responsible officers handling this request.

Non-Negotiable Compliance
These accommodations are non-negotiable and are essential for ensuring equal access to information. Failure to provide the requested accommodations may constitute a violation of the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act. Thank
you for ensuring compliance and accessibility in addressing this request.

FEE WAIVER REQUEST
Pursuant to 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii), I request a full fee waiver as:
✅ The request serves the public interest by ensuring transparency in government financial transactions.
✅ I am a whistleblower and journalist seeking information for public benefit, not commercial gain.

TIMEFRAME FOR RESPONSE
Pursuant to FOIA (5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(A)(i)) and Conn. Gen. Stat. § 1-210(c), I expect:
🔹 Acknowledgment within 4 business days.
🔹 Full response within 20 business days, or a legal justification for any delays.

CONSEQUENCES FOR NON-COMPLIANCE
Failure to comply by February 15, 2025, will result in:
✅ Formal FOIA appeals with U.S. DOJ Office of Information Policy (OIP).
✅ Complaint to Connecticut Freedom of Information Commission (FOIC).
✅ Judicial enforcement through federal and state courts.

FINAL NOTICE
This is a binding legal request under FOIA and state laws. Non-compliance will result in legal escalation and public exposure.

I expect immediate acknowledgment.

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
Founder, ABI Resources

Formal FOIA Request Submission and Accommodation Request for Forwarding to Relevant Parties

To all agencies, departments, and individuals included within this FOIA request:

This is a legally binding Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request pursuant to 5 U.S.C. § 552, Connecticut FOIA laws (Conn. Gen. Stat. §§ 1-200 et seq.), and all applicable federal and state transparency statutes.

This request is submitted in the interest of government accountability, financial oversight, and public transparency regarding the Connecticut Medicaid ABI Waiver Program, the Connecticut Comptroller’s Office, and any funding, contracts, or oversight related to the Connecticut Coalition Against Domestic Violence (CCADV).

Accommodation Request:
Under Title II of the ADA (42 U.S.C. § 12132) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. § 794), I formally request that this FOIA request be forwarded to any departments, offices, or personnel that may hold responsive records.

Additionally, to ensure accessibility and compliance with federal disability law, I request that:
✅ All records be provided in screen-reader compatible formats (searchable PDFs, plain-text files).
✅ Key findings be embedded directly in email responses (rather than external portals).
✅ All communications regarding this request remain within the original email chain for clarity and tracking.

Failure to forward this request as required by law, or failure to provide an exhaustive search and production of responsive documents, may be considered noncompliance under FOIA and will be subject to appeal, administrative complaints, and legal escalation if necessary.

A full response is expected within the statutory deadlines of FOIA (5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(A)(i)) and Conn. Gen. Stat. § 1-210(c).

David Medeiros
ABI Resources

I also request that, if possible and pursuant to Conn. Gen. Stat. § 1-212(d), fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest and not made for commercial gain. The requested documents will be made available to the public at MuckRock.com.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 4 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

DAVID MEDEIROS

title: Financial Records, Grant Allocations, and Correspondence Related to Connecticut Coalition Against Domestic Violence (CCADV) and Connecticut Comptroller’s Office (Office of the State Comptroller) (Federal Bureau of Investigation)

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Pursuant to 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E), I demand expedited processing based on:
✅ Urgency of public interest – The request involves government transparency, potential conflicts of interest, and the use of taxpayer funds.
✅ Risk of improper financial influence – Given Sean Scanlon’s position as Connecticut Comptroller and Meghan Scanlon’s leadership at Connecticut CCADV, there is a clear need for immediate disclosure.To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Connecticut Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

02/01/2025
Financial Records, Grant Allocations, and Correspondence Related to Connecticut Coalition Against Domestic Violence (CCADV) and Connecticut Comptroller’s Office
Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) Request – Legally Binding Public Records Demand

To:
Due to the complexity of government agencies, departments, sub-departments, and committees involved in this request, and in light of my disability, I formally request that all recipients of this FOIA request forward it to any and all relevant offices, divisions, personnel, or agencies that may hold responsive records.

This request is made in accordance with FOIA (5 U.S.C. § 552), the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) (42 U.S.C. § 12132), and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. § 794), ensuring my full and equal access to government records. I ask for reasonable assistance in processing this request, including identifying appropriate record holders and ensuring that all relevant entities conduct a thorough search including but not limited to the the following people and agencies listed below.

Federal Bureau of Investigation FBI
Connecticut Office of the Comptroller
Connecticut Department of Social Services (DSS)
Connecticut Office of Policy and Management (OPM)
Connecticut Governor’s Office
Connecticut Office of Victim Services (OVS)
U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) – Office of the Inspector General (OIG)
U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) – Office on Violence Against Women

Date: February 1, 2025

Subject: Immediate FOIA Request – Financial Records, Grant Allocations, and Correspondence Related to Connecticut Coalition Against Domestic Violence (CCADV) and Connecticut Comptroller’s Office
This request is submitted under my constitutional rights, whistleblower protections, and taxpayer interests pursuant to the following laws:

✅ Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) (5 U.S.C. § 552)
✅ Connecticut FOIA laws (Conn. Gen. Stat. §§ 1-200 et seq.)
✅ First and Fifth Amendments (Freedom of Information & Due Process Rights)
✅ Whistleblower Protection Act (5 U.S.C. § 2302)
✅ False Claims Act (31 U.S.C. §§ 3729–3733)
✅ Federal Funding Accountability and Transparency Act (31 U.S.C. § 6101)
✅ Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) (42 U.S.C. § 12101 et seq.)
✅ Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. § 794)

This FOIA request is made in the interest of government accountability, financial oversight, and transparency regarding Connecticut’s Medicaid ABI Waiver Program and potential conflicts of interest involving CCADV and the Connecticut Comptroller’s Office.

1. Connecticut State Budget Allocations to CCADV (2020–2025)
🔹 All state budget line items, funding allocations, and appropriations for domestic violence programs that provided funding to CCADV.
🔹 All discretionary grants, direct payments, or non-competitive funding allocations made to CCADV from Connecticut state agencies, including but not limited to DSS, OPM, and the Office of the Comptroller.
🔹 Records of budget changes, funding increases, or discretionary payments to CCADV since Meghan Scanlon became CEO.
🔹 Financial audits, budget justifications, and accountability reports related to CCADV funding.

2. Connecticut Comptroller’s Office – Transactions & Financial Oversight of CCADV
🔹 All financial disbursements from the Connecticut Comptroller’s Office to CCADV or any of its affiliated programs (2020-2025).
🔹 All contracts, agreements, invoices, or purchase orders involving the Connecticut Comptroller’s Office and CCADV.
🔹 All internal communications, memos, or correspondence related to CCADV funding, financial oversight, or policy decisions.

3. Connecticut Department of Social Services (DSS) – Grant Funding to CCADV
🔹 All contracts, agreements, and funding disbursement records between DSS and CCADV.
🔹 All emails, memos, or correspondence between DSS officials and CCADV leadership (including Meghan Scanlon) regarding funding, policies, or budget increases.
🔹 Records of grant application processes, funding approval criteria, and justification for any discretionary funding increases to CCADV.

4. Connecticut Office of Policy and Management (OPM) – Discretionary Funding Oversight
🔹 All financial records and internal communications regarding CCADV’s funding through discretionary grants or state allocations.
🔹 All documentation detailing OPM’s approval, oversight, and monitoring of funds allocated to CCADV.

5. Governor’s Office – Policy Influence & CCADV Funding
🔹 All communications (emails, memos, reports) between the Governor’s Office and CCADV leadership regarding funding, legislative priorities, or advocacy initiatives.
🔹 All meeting minutes, directives, or internal memos discussing the Governor’s role in funding CCADV or influencing domestic violence program funding.

6. Connecticut Office of Victim Services (OVS) – Judicial Branch Grant Funding to CCADV
🔹 All financial records, grant allocations, and award justifications given to CCADV through OVS.
🔹 All documentation related to federal VOCA (Victims of Crime Act) and VAWA (Violence Against Women Act) grants distributed to CCADV through state agencies.

7. Federal Oversight – U.S. DOJ & HHS Inspector General
🔹 All federal grant distributions (FVPSA, VAWA, VOCA) allocated to CCADV through Connecticut agencies.
🔹 All audits, compliance reviews, or fraud investigations into CCADV’s use of state or federal funding.
🔹 All records related to whistleblower complaints, fraud disclosures, or conflicts of interest concerning CCADV and state agencies.

8. Legal Mandates for Compliance
✅ National Archives & Records Administration v. Favish, 541 U.S. 157 (2004) – Government transparency is a constitutional right.
✅ Judicial Watch v. DHS, 857 F.3d 564 (D.C. Cir. 2017) – Agencies must provide evidence that no records exist.
✅ Burlington Northern & Santa Fe Railway Co. v. White, 548 U.S. 53 (2006) – Government retaliation includes obstructing access to information.

EXPEDITED PROCESSING REQUEST
Pursuant to 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(E), I demand expedited processing based on:
✅ Urgency of public interest – The request involves government transparency, potential conflicts of interest, and the use of taxpayer funds.
✅ Risk of improper financial influence – Given Sean Scanlon’s position as Comptroller and Meghan Scanlon’s leadership at CCADV, there is a clear need for immediate disclosure.

ADA & Civil Rights Accommodations
Under Title II of the ADA (42 U.S.C. § 12132) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. § 794), I demand:
ADA Accommodations Request
This request includes explicit ADA accommodations to address cognitive processing challenges resulting from my traumatic brain injury (TBI). These accommodations are legally required under Title II of the ADA (42 U.S.C. § 12132)
and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. § 794).

Requested ADA Accommodations
To ensure accessibility and compliance with ADA standards (42 U.S.C. § 12101 et seq.), I request the following accommodations for all communications and records:
Screen-Reader Compatible Formats

All documents must be provided in properly labeled PDFs or plain-text files.
Ensure that the documents are screen-reader compatible and retain clear, accessible formatting.
Exclusive MuckRock Platform Communication
All communications must occur exclusively via the MuckRock platform.
Do not send external links, emails, portals, passwords, codes, or require phone calls for access.
Text Embedded in Email Bodies

Key information must be embedded directly in the email body to facilitate comprehension and accessibility.

Simplified Summaries
Provide plain-language summaries for complex or legal documents to ensure clarity and understanding.

Identification of Responsible Officers
Include the full name, title, and contact information of all responsible officers handling this request.

Non-Negotiable Compliance
These accommodations are non-negotiable and are essential for ensuring equal access to information. Failure to provide the requested accommodations may constitute a violation of the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act. Thank
you for ensuring compliance and accessibility in addressing this request.

FEE WAIVER REQUEST
Pursuant to 5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(4)(A)(iii), I request a full fee waiver as:
✅ The request serves the public interest by ensuring transparency in government financial transactions.
✅ I am a whistleblower and journalist seeking information for public benefit, not commercial gain.

TIMEFRAME FOR RESPONSE
Pursuant to FOIA (5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(A)(i)) and Conn. Gen. Stat. § 1-210(c), I expect:
🔹 Acknowledgment within 4 business days.
🔹 Full response within 20 business days, or a legal justification for any delays.

CONSEQUENCES FOR NON-COMPLIANCE
Failure to comply by February 15, 2025, will result in:
✅ Formal FOIA appeals with U.S. DOJ Office of Information Policy (OIP).
✅ Complaint to Connecticut Freedom of Information Commission (FOIC).
✅ Judicial enforcement through federal and state courts.

FINAL NOTICE
This is a binding legal request under FOIA and state laws. Non-compliance will result in legal escalation and public exposure.

I expect immediate acknowledgment.

Sincerely,
David Medeiros
Founder, ABI Resources

*** Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI)
Urgent Request for Investigation into OSC Case Records, Altered Decisions, and Suppressed Reports

Formal FOIA Request Submission and Accommodation Request for Forwarding to Relevant Parties

To all agencies, departments, and individuals included within this FOIA request:

This is a legally binding Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request pursuant to 5 U.S.C. § 552, Connecticut FOIA laws (Conn. Gen. Stat. §§ 1-200 et seq.), and all applicable federal and state transparency statutes.

This request is submitted in the interest of government accountability, financial oversight, and public transparency regarding the Connecticut Medicaid ABI Waiver Program, the Connecticut Comptroller’s Office, and any funding, contracts, or oversight related to the Connecticut Coalition Against Domestic Violence (CCADV).

Accommodation Request:
Under Title II of the ADA (42 U.S.C. § 12132) and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. § 794), I formally request that this FOIA request be forwarded to any departments, offices, or personnel that may hold responsive records.

Additionally, to ensure accessibility and compliance with federal disability law, I request that:
✅ All records be provided in screen-reader compatible formats (searchable PDFs, plain-text files).
✅ Key findings be embedded directly in email responses (rather than external portals).
✅ All communications regarding this request remain within the original email chain for clarity and tracking.

Failure to forward this request as required by law, or failure to provide an exhaustive search and production of responsive documents, may be considered noncompliance under FOIA and will be subject to appeal, administrative complaints, and legal escalation if necessary.

A full response is expected within the statutory deadlines of FOIA (5 U.S.C. § 552(a)(6)(A)(i)) and Conn. Gen. Stat. § 1-210(c).

David Medeiros
ABI Resources

I also request that, if possible and pursuant to Conn. Gen. Stat. § 1-212(d), fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest and not made for commercial gain. The requested documents will be made available to the public at MuckRock.com.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 4 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

DAVID MEDEIROS

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

DAVID MEDEIROS

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

-     Any documented phone calls, telegrams, and other communications amongst Department of State staff members in reference to the country of Bangladesh, its people, and its language that occurred between March and December of 1971.

-     Any lines of communication between Department of State staff members and Bangladeshi leaders, including the country’s Prime Minister, that occurred during the aforementioned time period.

-     Any documents about Bangladesh’s Liberation War of 1971 that are not already available on the National Archives catalog.

Responsive documents will be made available to the general public. Additionally, this request is being made for personal and not commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. title: SPD Body camera footage of June 26 encampment sweep

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: SPD Body camera footage of June 26 encampment sweep
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

From 11:30 AM to 3:00 PM, all footage from body cameras of responding officers to the dispersal of the South River encampment on June 26, 2024.

In particular, the body camera footage of:

C.I.U. Supervisor Sgt. Sean Andrus
C.I.U. Specialist Ofc. Ryan Arundel
C.I.U. Specialist Ofc. Dan Musto
C.I.U. Specialist Ofc. Neil Sicard
C.I.U. Specialist Ofc. Joshua Gerrard

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. I am currently a student journalist at Emerson College that has reported on the South River encampment in the past. The nature of this request is one of transparency regarding a widely-publicized encampment sweep and falls squarely within the public interest of some of our City's most vulnerable. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Adam Nuñez

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Amherst-Pelham PD School Based Arrests
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

To whoever it may concern:

This letter constitutes a request pursuant to the Public Records Act, M. G. L.c.66, §10, for public records in the custody of your police department.
Under the Criminal Justice Reform Act, school districts and law enforcement agencies must “specify the manner and division of responsibility for collecting and reporting the school-based arrests, citations and court referrals of students to the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education” (DESE). DESE began collecting data on school-related arrests in the 2018-19 school year. In the 2019-20 school year, DESE has expanded that collection to include data on all referrals to law enforcement. DESE has defined these terms as follows, borrowing the same definitions used by the U.S. Department of Education since its 2009 Civil Rights Data Collection.
A school-related arrest “[r]efers to an arrest of a student for any activity conducted on school grounds, during off campus school activities (including while taking school transportation), or due to a referral by any school official. All school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”
A referral to law enforcement “[i]s an action by which a student is reported to any law enforcement agency or official, including a school police unit, for an incident that occurs on school grounds, during school-related events, or while taking school transportation, regardless of whether official action is taken. Citations, tickets, court referrals, and school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”

I request the following public records, as defined in M. G. L.c. 4, § 7 (twenty-sixth):

1. An extract of your records management system or database that includes each school-related arrest and each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced). Specifically, we request an extract of the database to include the following columns:
a. Date of arrest or referral to law enforcement
b. Time of arrest or referral to law enforcement
c. Charge (or charges)
d. Whether the individual(s) was arrested or referred to law enforcement
e. Sex of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
f. Age of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
g. Race of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
h. Ethnicity of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
i. Disability status of the individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
j. Whether the individual arrested or referred to law enforcement is a student at the school.
k. Name of arresting officer, if applicable, and
l. Badge number of the arresting officer or the officer that referred the youth to law enforcement, as applicable.

2. If such an extract of the database in question 1 is not possible, please provide police reports and school incident reports on each school-related arrest conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced).

3. Please provide an unduplicated count of arrested students for each school year including 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced).

4. If such an extract of the database in question 1 is not possible, please provide police reports and school incident reports on each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced), per the U.S. Department of Education’s Civil Rights Data Collection for that year. For each referral to law enforcement, please include the school, demographic, and incident information described in DESE’s School Safety and Discipline Report Data Handbook v. 20.0.

5. Please also provide an unduplicated counts of referrals to law enforcement (as defined above) for each school year including 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022 and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced).
As this request involves a matter of public interest and will not be used for any commercial purpose, we ask that all fees associated with this request be waived pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(k). The purpose of this request is to determine whether your school district and police department are complying with their reporting obligations under the Criminal Justice Reform Act. “The public has an interest in knowing whether public servants are carrying out their duties in an efficient and law-abiding manner.”

It would be ill-advised to impose a fee for data that your police department may have failed to report in violation of statutory and regulatory duty. Moreover, as you know, municipalities with a population of over 20,000 may not assess a fee for the first 2 hours of time spent searching for, compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. Finally, pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(i), a records access officer shall assess no fee greater than the lowest hourly rate of a person capable of compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. In the event that a charge is incurred for this request which you will not waive, please so indicate and include an itemization of estimated good faith costs.
Please provide public records to a requestor in an electronic format unless the record is not available in an electronic format. M. G. L.c 66, § 6A(d).
The Public Records Act requires that you comply with this request within ten (10) business days following receipt. If you believe that documents or data responsive to any request herein is not public record and thus not subject to disclosure, please set forth in writing the specific reasons for such assertion, including the specific exemption or exemptions that you believe apply. To the extent that you determine that records need to be redacted in order to be produced under any law protecting the privacy of named individuals, please do so rather than withholding them in their entirety.
If you have any questions about this request, or need additional time to respond, please contact me. Thank you in advance for your prompt response to this request.

Sincerely,
Kayla Fox
J.D. Candidate
Research Assistant
Center for Public Interest, Advocacy, and Collaboration
fox.kayl@northeastern.edu
(312) 718-0331

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kayla Fox

Joy Ann Jolie

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Belmont PD School Based Arrests
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

To whoever it may concern:

This letter constitutes a request pursuant to the Public Records Act, M. G. L.c.66, §10, for public records in the custody of your police department.
Under the Criminal Justice Reform Act, school districts and law enforcement agencies must “specify the manner and division of responsibility for collecting and reporting the school-based arrests, citations and court referrals of students to the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education” (DESE). DESE began collecting data on school-related arrests in the 2018-19 school year. In the 2019-20 school year, DESE has expanded that collection to include data on all referrals to law enforcement. DESE has defined these terms as follows, borrowing the same definitions used by the U.S. Department of Education since its 2009 Civil Rights Data Collection.
A school-related arrest “[r]efers to an arrest of a student for any activity conducted on school grounds, during off campus school activities (including while taking school transportation), or due to a referral by any school official. All school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”
A referral to law enforcement “[i]s an action by which a student is reported to any law enforcement agency or official, including a school police unit, for an incident that occurs on school grounds, during school-related events, or while taking school transportation, regardless of whether official action is taken. Citations, tickets, court referrals, and school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”

I request the following public records, as defined in M. G. L.c. 4, § 7 (twenty-sixth):

1. An extract of your records management system or database that includes each school-related arrest and each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced). Specifically, we request an extract of the database to include the following columns:
a. Date of arrest or referral to law enforcement
b. Time of arrest or referral to law enforcement
c. Charge (or charges)
d. Whether the individual(s) was arrested or referred to law enforcement
e. Sex of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
f. Age of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
g. Race of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
h. Ethnicity of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
i. Disability status of the individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
j. Whether the individual arrested or referred to law enforcement is a student at the school.
k. Name of arresting officer, if applicable, and
l. Badge number of the arresting officer or the officer that referred the youth to law enforcement, as applicable.

2. If such an extract of the database in question 1 is not possible, please provide police reports and school incident reports on each school-related arrest conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced).

3. Please provide an unduplicated count of arrested students for each school year including 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced).

4. If such an extract of the database in question 1 is not possible, please provide police reports and school incident reports on each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced), per the U.S. Department of Education’s Civil Rights Data Collection for that year. For each referral to law enforcement, please include the school, demographic, and incident information described in DESE’s School Safety and Discipline Report Data Handbook v. 20.0.

5. Please also provide an unduplicated counts of referrals to law enforcement (as defined above) for each school year including 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022 and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced).
As this request involves a matter of public interest and will not be used for any commercial purpose, we ask that all fees associated with this request be waived pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(k). The purpose of this request is to determine whether your school district and police department are complying with their reporting obligations under the Criminal Justice Reform Act. “The public has an interest in knowing whether public servants are carrying out their duties in an efficient and law-abiding manner.”

It would be ill-advised to impose a fee for data that your police department may have failed to report in violation of statutory and regulatory duty. Moreover, as you know, municipalities with a population of over 20,000 may not assess a fee for the first 2 hours of time spent searching for, compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. Finally, pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(i), a records access officer shall assess no fee greater than the lowest hourly rate of a person capable of compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. In the event that a charge is incurred for this request which you will not waive, please so indicate and include an itemization of estimated good faith costs.
Please provide public records to a requestor in an electronic format unless the record is not available in an electronic format. M. G. L.c 66, § 6A(d).
The Public Records Act requires that you comply with this request within ten (10) business days following receipt. If you believe that documents or data responsive to any request herein is not public record and thus not subject to disclosure, please set forth in writing the specific reasons for such assertion, including the specific exemption or exemptions that you believe apply. To the extent that you determine that records need to be redacted in order to be produced under any law protecting the privacy of named individuals, please do so rather than withholding them in their entirety.
If you have any questions about this request, or need additional time to respond, please contact me. Thank you in advance for your prompt response to this request.

Sincerely,
Kayla Fox
J.D. Candidate
Research Assistant
Center for Public Interest, Advocacy, and Collaboration
fox.kayl@northeastern.edu
(312) 718-0331

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kayla Fox

Belmont, Massachusetts ************************************************************************ Your record request #25-144 has been submitted successfully. This email confirms that the Town of Belmont has received your Public Records Request. Please watch your email for more updates and documents related to this request - be sure to watch your junk folder in case messages are filtered there.Per MGL Chapter 66, Section 10, and Acts of 2016, Chapter 121, the Town of Belmont will conduct research and prepare a response to your request within ten (10) business days. If necessary, we will notify you that we require the additional 15 days allowable under Massachusetts Public Records laws to complete your request.  If there will be a charge to fulfill your request we will provide you with a good faith estimate. The fee will include costs for labor that exceeds 2 hours. If you consent to the cost, you must authorize the Town to proceed with the research on the promise that you will pay the actual amount due. Payment of the fee must be received prior to delivery of the records. Please note that the Commonwealth schedule for reimbursement of expenses related to a Public Records Request follows: * $.05 per page – print or copy * the actual reproduction cost for unique items such as full-size plans or maps * plus the wages of the lowest-paid employee who can perform the research/copying or redacting work – the first two (2) hours are free.  The maximum rate allowed to be charged is $25.00 per hour.   * if exemptions, additional fees or time are required, the Town will petition the Supervisor of Public Records Records will be provided through this Public Records Portal, for the assigned request # and you will receive an email notification. Please be certain to check your junk mail or spam and add publicrecords@belmont-ma.gov as a safe sender to your address list. Please be advised that you have the right of administrative appeal to the Massachusetts Supervisor of Records under 950 CMR 32.08(1), and the right to seek judicial review of any unfavorable decision by commencing a civil action in the superior court pursuant to M.G.L. c. 66, §10A (c). ************************************************************************ Reply to this email or sign in to contact Belmont, Massachusetts.

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

To whoever it may concern:

This letter constitutes a request pursuant to the Public Records Act, M. G. L.c.66, §10, for public records in the custody of your police department.
Under the Criminal Justice Reform Act, school districts and law enforcement agencies must “specify the manner and division of responsibility for collecting and reporting the school-based arrests, citations and court referrals of students to the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education” (DESE). DESE began collecting data on school-related arrests in the 2018-19 school year. In the 2019-20 school year, DESE has expanded that collection to include data on all referrals to law enforcement. DESE has defined these terms as follows, borrowing the same definitions used by the U.S. Department of Education since its 2009 Civil Rights Data Collection.
A school-related arrest “[r]efers to an arrest of a student for any activity conducted on school grounds, during off campus school activities (including while taking school transportation), or due to a referral by any school official. All school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”
A referral to law enforcement “[i]s an action by which a student is reported to any law enforcement agency or official, including a school police unit, for an incident that occurs on school grounds, during school-related events, or while taking school transportation, regardless of whether official action is taken. Citations, tickets, court referrals, and school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”

I request the following public records, as defined in M. G. L.c. 4, § 7 (twenty-sixth):

1. An extract of your records management system or database that includes each school-related arrest and each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced). Specifically, we request an extract of the database to include the following columns:
a. Date of arrest or referral to law enforcement
b. Time of arrest or referral to law enforcement
c. Charge (or charges)
d. Whether the individual(s) was arrested or referred to law enforcement
e. Sex of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
f. Age of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
g. Race of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
h. Ethnicity of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
i. Disability status of the individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
j. Whether the individual arrested or referred to law enforcement is a student at the school.
k. Name of arresting officer, if applicable, and
l. Badge number of the arresting officer or the officer that referred the youth to law enforcement, as applicable.

2. If such an extract of the database in question 1 is not possible, please provide police reports and school incident reports on each school-related arrest conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced).

3. Please provide an unduplicated count of arrested students for each school year including 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced).

4. If such an extract of the database in question 1 is not possible, please provide police reports and school incident reports on each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced), per the U.S. Department of Education’s Civil Rights Data Collection for that year. For each referral to law enforcement, please include the school, demographic, and incident information described in DESE’s School Safety and Discipline Report Data Handbook v. 20.0.

5. Please also provide an unduplicated counts of referrals to law enforcement (as defined above) for each school year including 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022 and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced).
As this request involves a matter of public interest and will not be used for any commercial purpose, we ask that all fees associated with this request be waived pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(k). The purpose of this request is to determine whether your school district and police department are complying with their reporting obligations under the Criminal Justice Reform Act. “The public has an interest in knowing whether public servants are carrying out their duties in an efficient and law-abiding manner.”

It would be ill-advised to impose a fee for data that your police department may have failed to report in violation of statutory and regulatory duty. Moreover, as you know, municipalities with a population of over 20,000 may not assess a fee for the first 2 hours of time spent searching for, compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. Finally, pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(i), a records access officer shall assess no fee greater than the lowest hourly rate of a person capable of compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. In the event that a charge is incurred for this request which you will not waive, please so indicate and include an itemization of estimated good faith costs.
Please provide public records to a requestor in an electronic format unless the record is not available in an electronic format. M. G. L.c 66, § 6A(d).
The Public Records Act requires that you comply with this request within ten (10) business days following receipt. If you believe that documents or data responsive to any request herein is not public record and thus not subject to disclosure, please set forth in writing the specific reasons for such assertion, including the specific exemption or exemptions that you believe apply. To the extent that you determine that records need to be redacted in order to be produced under any law protecting the privacy of named individuals, please do so rather than withholding them in their entirety.
If you have any questions about this request, or need additional time to respond, please contact me. Thank you in advance for your prompt response to this request.

Sincerely,
Kayla Fox
J.D. Candidate
Research Assistant
Center for Public Interest, Advocacy, and Collaboration
fox.kayl@northeastern.edu
(312) 718-0331

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kayla Fox

Moreover, as you know, municipalities with a population of over 20,000 may not assess a fee for the first 2 hours of time spent searching for, compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. Finally, pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(i), a records access officer shall assess no fee greater than the lowest hourly rate of a person capable of compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. In the event that a charge is incurred for this request which you will not waive, please so indicate and include an itemization of estimated good faith costs.
Please provide public records to a requestor in an electronic format unless the record is not available in an electronic format. M. G. L.c 66, § 6A(d).
The Public Records Act requires that you comply with this request within ten (10) business days following receipt. If you believe that documents or data responsive to any request herein is not public record and thus not subject to disclosure, please set forth in writing the specific reasons for such assertion, including the specific exemption or exemptions that you believe apply. To the extent that you determine that records need to be redacted in order to be produced under any law protecting the privacy of named individuals, please do so rather than withholding them in their entirety.
If you have any questions about this request, or need additional time to respond, please contact me. Thank you in advance for your prompt response to this request.

Sincerely,
Kayla Fox
J.D. Candidate
Research Assistant
Center for Public Interest, Advocacy, and Collaboration
fox.kayl@northeastern.edu
(312) 718-0331

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kayla Fox

An extract of your records management system or database that includes each school-related arrest and each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced). a. Date of arrest or referral to law enforcement
b. Time of arrest or referral to law enforcement
c. Charge (or charges)
d. Whether the individual(s) was arrested or referred to law enforcement
e. Sex of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
f. Age of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
g. Race of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
h. Ethnicity of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
i. Disability status of the individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
j. Whether the individual arrested or referred to law enforcement is a student at the school.
k. Name of arresting officer, if applicable, and
l. Badge number of the arresting officer or the officer that referred the youth to law enforcement, as applicable.

2. If such an extract of the database in question 1 is not possible, please provide police reports and school incident reports on each school-related arrest conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced).

3. Please provide an unduplicated count of arrested students for each school year including 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced).

4. An extract of your records management system or database that includes each school-related arrest and each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced). Specifically, we request an extract of the database to include the following columns:
a. Date of arrest or referral to law enforcement
b. Time of arrest or referral to law enforcement
c. Charge (or charges)
d. Whether the individual(s) was arrested or referred to law enforcement
e. Sex of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
f. Age of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
g. Race of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
h. Ethnicity of individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
i. Disability status of the individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement
j. Whether the individual arrested or referred to law enforcement is a student at the school.
k. Name of arresting officer, if applicable, and
l. Badge number of the arresting officer or the officer that referred the youth to law enforcement, as applicable.

2. If such an extract of the database in question 1 is not possible, please provide police reports and school incident reports on each school-related arrest conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced).

3. Please provide an unduplicated count of arrested students for each school year including 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced).

4. If such an extract of the database in question 1 is not possible, please provide police reports and school incident reports on each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced), per the U.S. Department of Education’s Civil Rights Data Collection for that year. For each referral to law enforcement, please include the school, demographic, and incident information described in DESE’s School Safety and Discipline Report Data Handbook v. 20.0.

5. Please also provide an unduplicated counts of referrals to law enforcement (as defined above) for each school year including 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022 and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced).
As this request involves a matter of public interest and will not be used for any commercial purpose, we ask that all fees associated with this request be waived pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(k). The purpose of this request is to determine whether your school district and police department are complying with their reporting obligations under the Criminal Justice Reform Act. “The public has an interest in knowing whether public servants are carrying out their duties in an efficient and law-abiding manner.”

It would be ill-advised to impose a fee for data that your police department may have failed to report in violation of statutory and regulatory duty. Moreover, as you know, municipalities with a population of over 20,000 may not assess a fee for the first 2 hours of time spent searching for, compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. Finally, pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(i), a records access officer shall assess no fee greater than the lowest hourly rate of a person capable of compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. In the event that a charge is incurred for this request which you will not waive, please so indicate and include an itemization of estimated good faith costs.
Please provide public records to a requestor in an electronic format unless the record is not available in an electronic format. M. G. L.c 66, § 6A(d).
The Public Records Act requires that you comply with this request within ten (10) business days following receipt. If you believe that documents or data responsive to any request herein is not public record and thus not subject to disclosure, please set forth in writing the specific reasons for such assertion, including the specific exemption or exemptions that you believe apply. To the extent that you determine that records need to be redacted in order to be produced under any law protecting the privacy of named individuals, please do so rather than withholding them in their entirety.
If you have any questions about this request, or need additional time to respond, please contact me. Thank you in advance for your prompt response to this request.

Sincerely,
Kayla Fox
J.D. Candidate
Research Assistant
Center for Public Interest, Advocacy, and Collaboration
fox.kayl@northeastern.edu
(312) 718-0331

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kayla Fox

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Dracut PD School Based Arrests
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

To whoever it may concern:

This letter constitutes a request pursuant to the Public Records Act, M. G. L.c.66, §10, for public records in the custody of your police department.
Under the Criminal Justice Reform Act, school districts and law enforcement agencies must “specify the manner and division of responsibility for collecting and reporting the school-based arrests, citations and court referrals of students to the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education” (DESE). DESE began collecting data on school-related arrests in the 2018-19 school year. In the 2019-20 school year, DESE has expanded that collection to include data on all referrals to law enforcement. DESE has defined these terms as follows, borrowing the same definitions used by the U.S. Department of Education since its 2009 Civil Rights Data Collection.
A school-related arrest “[r]efers to an arrest of a student for any activity conducted on school grounds, during off campus school activities (including while taking school transportation), or due to a referral by any school official. All school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”
A referral to law enforcement “[i]s an action by which a student is reported to any law enforcement agency or official, including a school police unit, for an incident that occurs on school grounds, during school-related events, or while taking school transportation, regardless of whether official action is taken. Citations, tickets, court referrals, and school-related arrests are considered referrals to law enforcement.”

I request the following public records, as defined in M. G. L.c. 4, § 7 (twenty-sixth):

1. An extract of your records management system or database that includes each school-related arrest and each referral to law enforcement conducted during the 2018-2019, 2019-2020, 2020-2021, 2021-2022, and 2022-2023 school year (up until the day the records are produced). a. Date of arrest or referral to law enforcement

i. Disability status of the individual(s) arrested or referred to law enforcement

For each referral to law enforcement, please include the school, demographic, and incident information described in DESE’s School Safety and Discipline Report Data Handbook v. 20.0.

As this request involves a matter of public interest and will not be used for any commercial purpose, we ask that all fees associated with this request be waived pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(k). The purpose of this request is to determine whether your school district and police department are complying with their reporting obligations under the Criminal Justice Reform Act. “The public has an interest in knowing whether public servants are carrying out their duties in an efficient and law-abiding manner.”

It would be ill-advised to impose a fee for data that your police department may have failed to report in violation of statutory and regulatory duty. Finally, pursuant to 950 C.M.R. 32.07(2)(i), a records access officer shall assess no fee greater than the lowest hourly rate of a person capable of compiling, segregating, redacting and reproducing a requested record. In the event that a charge is incurred for this request which you will not waive, please so indicate and include an itemization of estimated good faith costs.

The Public Records Act requires that you comply with this request within ten (10) business days following receipt. If you believe that documents or data responsive to any request herein is not public record and thus not subject to disclosure, please set forth in writing the specific reasons for such assertion, including the specific exemption or exemptions that you believe apply. To the extent that you determine that records need to be redacted in order to be produced under any law protecting the privacy of named individuals, please do so rather than withholding them in their entirety.
If you have any questions about this request, or need additional time to respond, please contact me. Thank you in advance for your prompt response to this request.

Sincerely,
Kayla Fox

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: FOIL Request: 02/03/2025 (Ontario County District Attorney)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

Any and all records, including audio or video footage, investigative files, memos, depositions, reports, emails etc., related to an incident on 08/11/2020 involving Sergeant Kevin R. Sholly (For reference, please see the attached record, obtained through a records request, stating the occurrence of this incident).

If there are any datasets or tables pertaining to the requested information, please provide them in Microsoft Excel files rather than PDFs. For any relevant emails, please include all attachments to all messages.

Please do send records as they become available.

I would be happy to modify this request if doing so would reduce the time it will take you to comply. Do let me know if this would be necessary.

If any aspect of this request is unreasonable pursuant to FOIL, exempt from the law, or unavailable, that should not slow provision of the rest of the requested records.

If your agency finds a part of the request to be exempt from public release, the law requires that you do not withhold the document entirely but rather redact that part of the record.

If you choose to deny any portion of my request, please provide a written explanation for the denial, including a reference to the specific statutory exemption(s) authorizing the withholding of all or part of the record, as well as an explanation of why you believe disclosure is prevented by law (Article 6 Section 87.) Please also provide me with an email where I may send any appeals.

Please communicate with me by email rather than regular mail regarding my request. I would be happy to answer any questions that you have.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Sanjana Bhambhani
We contact the NYSP for any records concerning Officer Kevin Sholly.
